image.altText: The NT police emblem on the side of a vehicle.

props.synopsis: The police union has concerns the Northern Territory’s official crime statistics could be inaccurate, warning a "complex" $58 million data system is continuing to burden officers 14 months after its roll-out.

title.children: NT Police administrative workload 'doubled' by complex data system

image.altText: A bearded man wearing a white cap eats a banana.

props.synopsis: Professional tennis players have access to the world's most advanced sports drinks and gels to boost their performance, but dietitians say you can't beat the humble banana.

title.children: Bananas the best fuel for Australian Open players chewing through 200kg a day

image.altText: Domestic violence generic - proxy

props.synopsis: The Northern Territory government has indicated that $180 million in domestic violence funding will start flowing this month, but there will be changes to where it's spent. Sector workers say the need for this funding in the territory is "enormous".

title.children: NT government's $180m domestic violence funding to roll out this month

image.altText: Man sits on deck and smiles while sitting down

props.synopsis: Data from the Australian Competition Consumer Commission shows home and strata insurance in north Australia is "much more expensive" compared to the rest of the country.

title.children: 'Where does it stop?': Home insurance premiums continue to rise in NT

image.altText: A man in a black singlet is questioned by uniformed police

props.synopsis: An integrity expert has called for an investigation after footage of a prominent Darwin silk inside a police watch house was leaked to the media following his arrest on a drink-driving charge.

title.children: Call for police leak probe in Darwin barrister's drink-driving case

image.altText: Channel 9 Darwin

props.synopsis: Channel Nine has suddenly axed its Darwin television news bulletin, with staff told on Wednesday morning the local service was being cancelled immediately.

title.children: 'A very sad day': Channel Nine axes Darwin TV news bulletin

image.altText: Architects and supporters of the bark petition gathered in Derby, WA for the presentation of the documents.

props.synopsis: New documentary One Mind, One Heart tells the incredible true story behind the Yirrkala bark petitions and follows their repatriation journey back home.

title.children: A daughter's quest to bring her father's monumental bark petition home

image.altText: Australian flag, Indigenous flag

props.synopsis: Because January 26 falls on a Sunday this year, many people will get a long weekend thanks to a public holiday on Monday.

title.children: When is the Australia Day public holiday this year?

image.altText: Mixed doubles partners on court whispering what their next shot will be

props.synopsis: Australians are guaranteed to be crowned champions as two Aussie duos contest the mixed doubles final. Follow live.

title.children: All-Australian mixed doubles final, men's semis on day 13

image.altText: A double story house being build with timber frames at the top and a builder to the left and far right

props.synopsis: The election policy will be launched in a National Press Club address on Friday.

title.children: Albanese to announce $10,000 cash for apprentices who build homes

image.altText: Donald Trump looks over his shoulder while wearing a suit with a red tie.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump has ordered the release of records for several high-profile assassinations including former president John F Kennedy within 15 days, and Martin Luther King's death.

title.children: Trump orders release of JFK assassination records — as it happened

image.altText: The PM with a face mask

props.synopsis: It's been about five years since the first case of COVID-19 was confirmed in Australia. This is what Australia living through "unprecedented times" looks like in numbers.

title.children: COVID-19 hit Australia five years ago. These numbers show its impact

image.altText: An ASX share market digital board listing stocks in green and red lighting alongside the ASX logo

props.synopsis: The ASX 200 is on track for a weekly gain. Wall Street ended higher as investors assessed a mixed bag of corporate earnings and digested US President Donald Trump's calls for cuts in interest rates and oil prices. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: ASX on the rise after S&P 500 touches all-time high

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Australian gold price touches record high, above $4,400 an ounce
ASX on track for best week in a month despite energy drag
ACTU welcomes $10,000 cost-of-living boost for apprentices

image.altText: Karla Sofía Gascón walking through a public space with a bag on her shoulder.

props.synopsis: Trans actress Karla Sofía Gascón makes Oscars history, an Australian cinematographer heading for gold and more from today's Academy Award nominations

title.children: All the snubs, surprises and successes in the 2025 Oscar nominations

image.altText: A young Aboriginal girl is doing ballet wearing traditional clothes. She is wearing brown emu feathers and is painted in ochre

props.synopsis: Australia Day brings up mixed emotions and opinions for many people. Despite this, there is a growth in First Nations cultural festivals being held on the day and this is why.

title.children: ‘Don’t let politics divide us’: Why there’s growth of First Nations festivals on Jan 26

image.altText: Baby Penguin sitting in a burrow

props.synopsis: A sudden drop in adult little penguin numbers at Bicheno on Tasmania's east coast has led to alarm for the fate of the colony as penguin chicks reliant on parents are seen dying.

title.children: Tours cancelled as adult penguins fail to return to young at seaside town

image.altText: statue wrapped in black plastic and cordoned off by fencing

props.synopsis: Vandals have caused $140,000 damage to several bronze statues of prime ministers in Ballarat Botanical Gardens.

title.children: Prime ministers' heads severed and stolen from bronze statues in Ballarat

image.altText: Randwick's Captain James Cook statue splashed with red paint

props.synopsis: A statue of Captain James Cook in Sydney's east has been splashed with red paint and had the sandstone damaged for the second time in 12 months.

title.children: Sydney Captain Cook statue splashed with red paint ahead of Australia Day

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: An aerial shot shows the PARQ Ubud complex under construction in the middle of rice fields and verdant strips of trees.

props.synopsis: Balinese authorities have finally had enough and sent hundreds of police to shut down a luxury villa complex known to locals as the "Russian village" after years of simmering tension and suspicion about building permit violations.

title.children: A 'Russian village' at the centre of backlash in Bali has now been shut down

image.altText: Blue police tape near crime scene

props.synopsis: Nine people have been charged over their involvement in antisemitic attacks in Sydney, but none have been charged with terrorism. Researchers say it's harder to meet that threshold.

title.children: Why Sydney's antisemitic attacks do not meet the definition of terrorism

image.altText: Oda pumps fist after game.

props.synopsis: Japanese players Tokido Oda and Yui Kamiji hold the world number one ranking in men's and women's wheelchair tennis as they roll in to the Australian Open finals. So how did Japan advance so far in the sport?

title.children: How Japan emerged as a wheelchair tennis powerhouse

image.altText: Police tape in the foreground with trees and car in the background

props.synopsis: Detectives from the Child Protection Investigation Unit and specialist police from Crime and Intelligence Command's Child Trauma Unit are investigating the death of a two-month-old girl.

title.children: Two-month-old baby girl dies in Brisbane hospital after suffering 'life-threatening injuries'

image.altText: Crowds of people hold their nose while they look on at a large flower blooming inside a tent.

props.synopsis: More than 20,000 people have lined up to get a whiff of the rare flower which stinks like "chicken you've left out a little too long".

title.children: It's official: Sydney's hottest ticket in town absolutely stinks

image.altText: A tree that's been logged in the middle of a forest.

props.synopsis: There are calls for an end to logging in forests being considered for the Great Koala National Park, as the government signals that it's close to completing the required assessment process.

title.children: Great Koala National Park assessment area logged despite government pledge

image.altText: Green plant and smoke in front of brown curtain

props.synopsis: Have you been paying attention to the news this week? Let's see what you've got.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Trump's comeback and a blooming corpse flower

image.altText: GettyImages-81453958

props.synopsis: Reaching the top of the junior tennis world should indicate a player is on the path to tennis stardom — but there's a reason why that isn't the case.

title.children: Why winning a junior slam doesn't guarantee stardom

image.altText: A close up of Anthony Albanese in a suit.

props.synopsis: Anthony Albanese points to the array of measures his government has taken to tackle the scourge of antisemitism. But he can't escape the impression of seeming perennially on the back foot and often lacking adequate empathy and sensitivity in dealing with the issue.

title.children: Albanese struggles to strike the right note on antisemitism

props.synopsis: Italian pilot Dario Costa reached a top speed of 350 km/h as he followed one of the world's most difficult downhill ski runs.

title.children: Italian stunt pilot flies down Austria's legendary Streif ski run

image.altText: A man cleans an elephant foot through a metal cage.

props.synopsis: Moving home is always stressful. But for Melbourne's much-loved elephants, a shift to Werribee promises to help the herd grow and thrive.

title.children: Keepers hope tragedy at Melbourne Zoo can save the rest of the herd

image.altText: A man in a white t shirt sat on the ground as a woman stands next to him carrying a brown bag

props.synopsis: One of the constables remains in hospital in a serious but stable condition after receiving significant head injuries in the "incredibly violent" attack.

title.children: Men charged over alleged Newtown bashing of off-duty police officers

image.altText: A woman with hair tied back in a bun, wears green tee, black shorts, leans into a child holding a workbook.

props.synopsis: Back-to-school preparations are in full swing, but a growing number of parents are abandoning traditional education.

title.children: More parents turn to homeschooling as attitudes towards education change

image.altText: Sun rays through the Surfers Paradise sign.

props.synopsis: The heatwave gripping Queensland is set to intensify today before a cooler change sweeps through in time for the Australia Day long weekend.

title.children: Queensland's heatwave expected to intensify with a top of 37C in Brisbane

image.altText: A man looks at the camera with a blank expression. There is a flag flying in the background.

props.synopsis: The Australian flag can evoke a range of feelings from pride and camaraderie to exclusion and division. Here are some reasons why these people have made it a feature of their homes.

title.children: Inside the yards where the Australian flag flies high

image.altText: A smiling woman standing in a high green crop, wears black, has short black hair, glasses. Blue sky with clouds scattered.

props.synopsis: A flooding event has enabled cereal and hay crops to be grown on dry lake beds in far western NSW, presenting a unique opportunity for some pastoralists.

title.children: Once-in-10-years floodwaters turn dry lake beds into oasis of green
